meta.content: KFeO2 with corner-shared FeO4 frameworks as a new type of cathode material in potassium-ion batteries
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry 2019 23:11
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2019 Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: KFeO2 is presented as a new type of cathode material for potassium-ion batteries. In contrast to LiFeO2 and NaFeO2, KFeO2 has tetrahedrally coordinated Fe3+ ions linked by three-dimensional corner-sharing. When chemically oxidized, KFeO2 releases ca. 0.3 K+ (K0.7FeO2) and shows no apparent changes in X-ray diffraction patterns. Rietveld refinement of KFeO2 and K0.7FeO2 reveals negligible variation in the unit cell dimension and in the basic structure, but noticeable differences in FeO4 volumes and inter-tetrahedra angles due to the Jahn-Teller active Fe4+ (eg2t2g2) in K0.7FeO2. The refinement also shows no preferential extraction of K+ from two possible sites (K1 and K2), which coincides with the results from density-functional-theory calculation. In accordance with the compositional and structural analysis, KFeO2 delivers a reversible capacity of 60 mAh g−1 (ca. 0.28 K+) during the initial charge/discharge (C/D), showing a plateau-like voltage response at 3.43 V vs. K/K+. In-operando diffraction studies also show no distinctive signs of pattern evolution, which is likely due to the structural similarities of KFeO2 and K0.7FeO2. With repeated cycling, however, the reversible capacity of KFeO2 continuously decreases and falls to 30 mAh g−1 after 50 C/D cycles. The repeated changes in the FeO4 tetrahedra geometry appear to cause a decrease in the crystallinity of KFeO2, which eventually aggravates the facile K+ transport. The results of this study show that the practicality of KFeO2 can be realized via improvements of cyclability by mitigating the Jahn-Teller effect (for example, isovalent doping with Al3+or Ga3+).

meta.content: KFeO2 with corner-shared FeO4 frameworks as a new type of cathode material in potassium-ion batteries - Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry

KFeO2 is presented as a new type of cathode material for potassium-ion batteries. In contrast to LiFeO2 and NaFeO2, KFeO2 has tetrahedrally coordinated Fe3+ ions linked by three-dimensional corner-sharing. When chemically oxidized, KFeO2 releases ca. 0.3 K+ (K0.7FeO2) and shows no apparent changes in X-ray diffraction patterns. Rietveld refinement of KFeO2 and K0.7FeO2 reveals negligible variation in the unit cell dimension and in the basic structure, but noticeable differences in FeO4 volumes and inter-tetrahedra angles due to the Jahn-Teller active Fe4+ (eg2t2g2) in K0.7FeO2. The refinement also shows no preferential extraction of K+ from two possible sites (K1 and K2), which coincides with the results from density-functional-theory calculation. In accordance with the compositional and structural analysis, KFeO2 delivers a reversible capacity of 60 mAh g−1 (ca. 0.28 K+) during the initial charge/discharge (C/D), showing a plateau-like voltage response at 3.43 V vs. K/K+. In-operando diffraction studies also show no distinctive signs of pattern evolution, which is likely due to the structural similarities of KFeO2 and K0.7FeO2. With repeated cycling, however, the reversible capacity of KFeO2 continuously decreases and falls to 30 mAh g−1 after 50 C/D cycles. The repeated changes in the FeO4 tetrahedra geometry appear to cause a decrease in the crystallinity of KFeO2, which eventually aggravates the facile K+ transport. The results of this study show that the practicality of KFeO2 can be realized via improvements of cyclability by mitigating the Jahn-Teller effect (for example, isovalent doping with Al3+or Ga3+).

head.title: KFeO2 with corner-shared FeO4 frameworks as a new type of cathode material in potassium-ion batteries | SpringerLink

frameworks as a new type of cathode material in potassium-ion batteries

div.p:
KFeO
2
is presented as a new type of cathode material for potassium-ion batteries. In contrast to LiFeO
2

. With repeated cycling, however, the reversible capacity of KFeO

Layered transition metal oxides are of importance as cathode materials in lithium- and sodium-ion batteries [
1
,
2
]. With few exceptions, most first-row transition metals (TMs) produce stable layered compounds under normal synthetic conditions, in which TM layers, composed of edge-shared octahedra, are sandwiched between lithium or sodium octahedron layers in an alternating fashion [
3
,
4
,
5
]. This structure is energetically favored with relatively small-sized alkaline ions (Li
+
and Na
+
), because the separation between ions within a lithium or sodium layer is relatively distant. This situation changes drastically, however, when the radius of alkaline ions is so large that the electrostatic repulsion between them becomes significant. In fact, only KScO
2
and KCrO
2
are known to exist as a K
+
-stoichiometric layered structure among K(TM)O
2
(TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) in the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD). This implies that strong K
+
-K
+
repulsion in a K
+
-stoichiometric layered structure causes a destabilization of the compound and/or leads to the formation of a K
+
-deficient layered structure [
6
,
7
].

Recently, potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) have drawn attention as a viable alternative to lithium-ion batteries, which currently dominate the market. The studies on KIBs have been motivated mainly by the possible use of graphite anodes for K
+
accommodation [
8
,
9
] and by the low standard reduction potential of K/K
+
, which compares with Li/Li
+
. The selection of layered compounds as a promising option for KIB cathodes was not surprising since the high strain that is caused by the extraction/insertion of large-sized K
+
cations can be more easily relieved in a layered structure. Various K
+
-deficient layered compounds, including K
x
MnO
2
[
10
,
11
], K
0.7
Fe
1/2
Mn
1/2
O
2
[
12
], K
0.67
Ni
0.17
Co
0.17
Mn
0.66
O
2
[
13
], K
x
CoO
2
[
14
,
15
], and K
x
CrO
2
[
16
,
17
,
18
], have already been reported. However, K
+
-stoichiometric layered compounds that are more compatible with a graphite anode in a full-cell configuration are rare (KCrO
2
[
6
] and KCrS
2
[
19
]) due to electrostatic K
+
-K
+
repulsion, as mentioned above.

The crystal structure of KFeO
2
is distinctive from a layered structure. In contrast to LiFeO
2
and NaFeO
2
that are stable in a conventional layered structure, Fe
3+
lies in a tetrahedral site in KFeO
2
(KAlO
2
structure type, orthorhombic,
Pbca
). K
+
cations locate within a large void formed by corner-shared FeO
4
tetrahedra and can migrate via multiple diffusion channels [
20
,
21
]. Based on these facts, K(TM)O
2
isostructural to KAlO
2
has long been considered a solid-state electrolyte for K
+
transport [
22
,
23
].

Herein, we describe KFeO
2
as a new type of KIB cathodes. To the best of our knowledge, no compounds with a comparable structure are being used as a cathode material in secondary ion batteries. In this study, we show that KFeO
2
can reversibly extract/insert ca. 0.3 K
+
at a pseudo-stationary potential of + 3.43 V vs. K/K
+
during charge/discharge (C/D), maintaining the structural features and dimensions. The possible diffusion pathways of two non-equivalent K
+
ions are also discussed via density-functional-theory (DFT) calculations. The reason for relatively fast capacity decay is also discussed based on the Jahn-Teller distortion of a FeO
4
tetrahedron, which provides insight for a design of new cathode materials with the same type of structure.

All chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich unless otherwise mentioned and were used as received. KFeO
2
was prepared via a conventional solid-state method. K
2
CO
3
(anhydrous 99%) and Fe
2
O
3
(99.9%) were mixed and homogenized using agate mortar. The mixture was placed in an alumina crucible and transferred to an alumina tube furnace. The temperature was raised to 900 °C at 5 °C min
−1
and held for 12 h under a continuous flow of Ar. The sample was naturally cooled within a furnace and was immediately transferred to an Ar-filled glove box for storage.

As-prepared KFeO
2
, chemically oxidized K
0.7
FeO
2
, and electrode films were subjected to diffraction studies using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku ULTIMA 4 equipped with Cu K
α
radiation,
λ
= 1.5406 Å). The XRD patterns were obtained at a scan rate of 2° min
−1
for the samples sealed in an air tight holder (2392B101, Rigaku). The elemental compositions were determined via inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Varian 720 ES) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM-7100F) coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Structural evolution during C/D was monitored by collecting in situ XRD patterns from a synchrotron X-ray source at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (beamline 3D, Korea). The data were collected on an MAR345 image plate with an incident wavelength of 1.03337 Å (12 keV).

DFT calculations along with a nudged elastic band (NEB) method were performed to evaluate the K
+
migration barriers for several different channels in KFeO
2
. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parameterized by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [
24
] in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP5.3) [
25
,
26
] was employed as an exchange correlation potential. Projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials [
27
,
28
] were used along with a cutoff energy of 500 eV and the k-mesh interval was maintained below 0.25 eV (5 × 3 × 2 k-mesh), based on the Monkhorst–Pack scheme [
29
]. Structural relaxation was implemented with convergence thresholds of 10
−6
eV and 10
−4
eV/Å for the total energy and ionic force components, respectively. The convergence threshold of ionic relaxation was 10
−1
eV/Å for all NEB calculations. A KFeO
2
unit cell was used for all calculations because we confirmed that the use of either a 2 × 1 × 1 supercell or a unit cell for the NEB calculation resulted in no difference for a particular channel (K1-K1).

The electrodes were prepared by mixing 70 wt% KFeO
2
with 10 wt% acetylene black (MTI, USA), and 20 wt% polytetrafluoroethylene binder in an Ar-filled glove box. The slurry was spread onto aluminum foil substrates. The coated electrodes were dried under pressure at 120 °C on a hot plate for 5 h in a glove box. The half cells were assembled into 2032 coin cells using potassium metal as the counter/reference electrode. The electrolyte was 0.8 M of potassium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (KFSI) in dimethyl ether (DME). The galvanostatic C/D cycles were performed using an automatic WBCS 3000 battery cycler (WonATech) in a potential range of 1.5–3.7 V (vs. K/K
+
). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out by applying a 3.00 ± 0.01 V AC signal over a frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 1 kHz (PARSTAT 2273). The obtained EIS spectra were analyzed using
Z
view software (Scribner and Associates Inc.), with an equivalent circuit of [
R
s
-(
R
CT
//
CPE
)-
W
], in which
R
s
and
R
CT
are the serial and charge-transfer resistances, respectively,
CPE
is a constant-phase element associated with charge-transfer, and
W
is the Warburg impedance. All electrochemical measurements were carried out at 20 °C.

KFeO
2
, iso-structural to a low-temperature phase of KAlO
2
, was synthesized at 900 °C under air. The XRD pattern of as-prepared KFeO
2
was well matched with a standard pattern (ICSD 157785) of the space group of
Pbca
in an orthorhombic lattice (Fig.
1a
), in which corner-shared FeO
4
tetrahedra form a three-dimensional framework (Fig.
1a
inset). When exposed to ambient air, the most intense peak at 2
θ
= 31.5° was continuously changed with an increase in time (Fig.
1b
). After 20 min, the peak began to decrease in intensity and to increase in width, which signified a reduction in the crystalline sizes. Further exposure resulted in the appearance of a set of unknown peaks between 32° and 33°. Figure
1b
, therefore, illustrates how KFeO
2
is moisture-sensitive, which is characteristic of most KIB cathodes [
6
,
19
]. The color of the air-exposed powder (dark brown) was also distinctively different from that of as-prepared KFeO
2
(greenish brown, Fig.
1b
inset).

a
XRD patterns of as-synthesized KFeO
2
and chemically oxidized powder with a standard pattern (ICSD 157785). Inset figure shows the atomic arrangement in a unit cell of KFeO
2
.
b
Changes in the XRD patterns with time when exposed to ambient air. Inset photos show the color change of KFeO
2
powders after long-time exposure. Numbers are exposure time in min

In order to confirm the possibility for K
+
extraction, KFeO
2
was subjected to chemical oxidation by Br
2
. The XRD pattern of Br
2
-treated KFeO
2
was almost identical to that of pristine KFeO
2
. The changes in peak positions and relative peak intensities were visually indiscernible.

Since visually identical XRD patterns do not necessarily mean the electro-inactivity of KFeO
2
(i.e., no K
+
extraction), compositional analysis was performed on pristine KFeO
2
and Br
2
-treated KFeO
2
. FESEM images and corresponding EDX results are shown in Fig.
2
. The FESEM images showed ca. 5-μm KFeO
2
particles with no characteristic morphology (Fig.
2a
). The EDX spectrum of pristine KFeO
2
revealed a composition of K
0.96
FeO
1.99
, indicating the formation of stoichiometric KFeO
2
. Based on the EDX maps, it was also obvious that the elements were homogeneously distributed over a particle. On the other hand, the EDX spectrum of Br
2
-treated KFeO
2
showed a noticeable decrease in the K content (Fig.
2b
). The composition of K
0.70
FeO
1.99
clearly indicated the K
+
extraction by Br
2
, despite visual invariance in the XRD pattern. Note the decrease in the intensity of K in the EDX maps. Elemental analysis via ICP-AES also corresponded with the results from EDX. K/Fe ratios of 1.02 and 0.72 were obtained for pristine KFeO
2
and Br
2
-treated KFeO
2
, respectively, which again supported the electroactivity of KFeO
2
and the extraction of ca. 0.3 K
+
by Br
2
. Hereafter, the composition of oxidized KFeO
2
will be denoted as K
0.7
FeO
2
.

FESEM images and corresponding EDX spectra for
a
pristine KFeO
2
and
b
chemically oxidized powder. Elemental maps for K, Fe, and O are also compared

To understand the structural change caused by the extraction of K
+
, the XRD patterns of KFeO
2
and K
0.7
FeO
2
were subjected to Rietveld refinement with the
Pbca
space group (Fig.
3
). During the refinement, the site occupancy factors (SOFs) of all the elements were fixed at 1.00 with the exception of the K1 and K2 sites in K
0.7
FeO
2
, in which relative populations were varied with a fixed sum of 1.40. The experimental (red dots) and calculated (black line) profiles matched well with the orthorhombic crystal setting of the
Pbca
space group for both patterns. The best fits were obtained when the unit cell parameters were
a
= 5.6017(10),
b
= 11.2624(2), and
c
= 15.9328(2) Å in KFeO
2
and
a
= 5.5970(3),
b
= 11.2596(5), and
c
= 15.9163(8) Å in K
0.7
FeO
2
. This indicated that the unit cell contracted slightly after K
+
extraction, but the difference was negligible (1005.18 and 1003.04 Å
3
for KFeO
2
and K
0.7
FeO
2
, respectively). Preferential K
+
extraction from a specific K
+
site was inconspicuous. A slightly smaller SOF for the K2 site was obtained in K
0.7
FeO
2
(0.74 and 0.66 for K1 and K2, respectively). The similar SOFs were not surprising when the possible diffusion paths were considered (see below). The refinement results and atomic coordinates are summarized in Table
1
and Table
2
.

Full-pattern Rietveld refinement fits for the XRD patterns of
a
as-synthesized KFeO
2
and
b
Br
2
-oxidized K
0.7
FeO
2
using an orthorhombic structure in the
Pbca
space group. Red dots, black line, and blue line represent the experimental, calculated, and difference profiles, respectively. The vertical tick marks above the difference profile denote the position of Bragg reflections

figcaption.b:
Table 1 Fractional atomic coordinates, thermal factors (
U
), and site occupancy factors (SOF) obtained after Rietveld refinement on the powder XRD data of KFeO
2
using a hexagonal structure in the
Pbca
space group

Table 2 Fractional atomic coordinates, thermal factors (
U
), and site occupancy factor (SOF) obtained after Rietveld refinement on the powder XRD data of K
0.7
FeO
2
using a hexagonal structure in the
Pbca
space group

div.p:
Though the unit cell dimensions were almost invariant, however, the FeO
4
geometry was significantly altered after K
+
extraction (Fig.
4a
). The volumes of Fe(1)O
4
and Fe(2)O
4
in KFeO
2
(3.12 and 4.22 Å
3
) were changed to 3.32 and 3.48 Å
3
in K
0.7
FeO
2
. This drastic change in the tetrahedron volume of Fe(2)O
4
was likely due to the Jahn-Teller effect of Fe
4+
ions (e
g
2
t
2g
2
). In order to relieve the strain, inter-tetrahedra angles between Fe(1)O
4
and Fe(2)O
4
were also substantially changed. For example, ∠O2-O3-O4 of 85.1° in KFeO
2
was reduced to 65.5° in K
0.7
FeO
2
. The K
+
extraction, therefore, is believed to stimulate the rearrangement of atomic positions while maintaining the overall unit cell configuration.

a
Difference in the volumes and the relative orientation of Fe(1)O
4
and Fe(2)O
4
in KFeO
2
and K
0.7
FeO
2
.
b
Five migration paths along the [100] and [010] directions.
c
Comparison of activation energy barriers for five migration paths, obtained by NEB calculations

Orthorhombic KFeO
2
is known to have three-dimensional K
+
conducting channels and to show moderate ionic conductivities at high temperatures [
20
,
21
]. The channels are aligned along the [100] and [010] directions, through which K
+
ions migrate in a zig-zag mode (Fig.
4b
). Because of non-equivalent Fe and O arrangements, each path has a unique window in size and form [
21
], which results in different migration energy barriers (i.e., path 1: K1 → K1, path 2: K1 → K1, path 3: K2 → K2, path 4: K2 → K1, path 5: K1 → K2). As expected, the energy profiles obtained from the NEB calculations for five different paths showed anisotropic activation energies (
E
a
) (Fig.
4c
). The
E
a
lies in a range from 0.39 to 0.91 eV (37.5 to 87.4 kJ mol
−1
). In particular, the migrations through path 1 and path 2 (K1 → K1 → K1) and through path 3 (K2 → K2 → K2) showed
E
a
values that were lower than those through path 4 and path 5 (K2 → K1 → K2), which had
E
a
values (48.8–58.5 kJ mol
−1
) similar to the experimental value (52.6 kJ mol
−1
) [
21
,
30
]. This indicates that most K
+
transport is likely to occur along [100] with no preference in the K
+
extraction from K1 and K2 sites. Note that these results correspond with the Rietveld results of K
0.7
FeO
2
, which also showed similar SOFs for the K1 and K2 sites.

Reversible K
+
extraction/insertion was examined via an electrochemical C/D between 1.5 and 3.7 V at 20 mA g
−1
(Fig.
5
). The C/D profiles during the initial 2 cycles show that KFeO
2
can be electrochemically oxidized at an average voltage of 3.55 V with a capacity of 70 mAh g
−1
. Assuming no electrolyte decomposition, this charge capacity corresponded to the extraction of 0.33 mol K
+
, which matched well with the composition of chemically oxidized K
0.7
FeO
2
. The following discharge also revealed a plateau-like voltage profile, which was centered at 3.43 V with a discharge capacity of 60 mAh g
−1
. The reversibility was retained during the second C/D, but capacities were slightly decreased. Though not perfectly flat, the corresponding d
Q
/d
V
curves showed well-defined peaks with a separation of 0.12 V (Fig.
5
, left inset). It should be mentioned that we limited the high-voltage cutoff to 3.7 V because a further increase in the cutoff aggravated the reversibility (Fig.
5
, right inset).

First and second C/D profiles of KFeO
2
in DME of 0.8 M KFSI between 1.5 and 3.7 V vs. K/K
+
at 10 mAh g
−1
. Inset (left) shows corresponding d
Q
/d
V
curves. The first C/D profile, when the high-voltage cutoff is increased to 4.0 V, is also shown in the left inset

The structural reversibility was also confirmed by in-operando synchrotron XRD during the first C/D cycle at a rate of 10 mA g
−1
. As ex situ XRD studies have shown that the XRD patterns were invariant during charge. No apparent changes in the peak positions and the peak intensities were observed. Remarkably, following discharge also revealed the same XRD patterns, which clearly validated retention of the KFeO
2
structure during the reversible extraction/insertion of 0.3 K
+
for the initial C/D cycles (Fig.
6
).

In-operando synchrotron XRD patterns with charge/discharge at 10 mAh g
−1

KFeO
2
, however, showed relatively fast capacity decay (Fig.
7a
and inset). Discharge capacities were continuously decreased with cycling. After 50 C/D cycles, KFeO
2
retained ca. 50% of the initial discharge capacity (29.8 mAh g
−1
) and showed large overpotentials. We tested the cell performance under various conditions by changing electrolytes, binders, and cell fabrication processes to improve the cyclability. All the attempts, however, resulted in similar capacity fading, which implied that the capacity fading can be ascribed to an intrinsic instability of the crystalline structure of KFeO
2
. A comparison of the EIS spectra between two cells cycled for 2 and 50 cycles of C/D revealed a clear difference (Fig.
7b
). The EIS spectrum of KFeO
2
after 2 C/D cycles showed a depressed semi-circle with 0.609 kΩ in the distance intersecting with a real axis, which corresponded to a charge-transfer resistance (
R
CT
). This R
CT
was significantly increased to 2.47 kΩ after 50 C/D cycles. The aggravation of cell performance after repeated cycling was, therefore, believed to be due to an increase in the R
CT
, which could be caused by an alteration in the crystallinity.

a
Changes in the C/D profiles and increases in the over-potentials with repeated cycling. Numbers indicate the cycle number and the inset shows the changes in discharge capacities and Coulombic efficiencies during 50 C/D cycles.
b
Comparison of EIS spectra of KFeO
2
at 3.00 ± 0.01 V after 2 and 50 cycles.
c
Ex situ XRD patterns of KFeO
2
films, which show a decrease in the crystallinity with cycling.
d
FESEM images of KFeO
2
after 2 and 50 cycles

To confirm a change in the crystallinity, we compared the XRD patterns after C/D cycles (Fig.
7c
). Indeed, while the diffraction patterns for the films after the second charge and the second discharge were the same as that of the pristine film, the KFeO
2
film after 50 C/D cycles showed a significant reduction in the peak intensities. Since no emergence of new peaks was observed, the weakening of the peak intensities likely signified a decrease in crystallinity rather than a transformation of the cystalline structures. The amorphitization of KFeO
2
with repeated cycling also altered the film morphology (Fig.
7d
). A comparison of the FESEM images of the films after 2 and 50 C/D cycles indicated that the initial particle shapes were retained after 2 cycles, but that no characteristic morphologies remained after 50 cycles. Featureless aggregations of the particles due to amorphitization were evident.

Therefore, the gradual deterioration in the structural stability of KFeO
2
with cycling seemed to be ascribed to Jahn-Teller distortion by tetraherally coordinated Fe
4+
ions. As disclosed in the previous Rietveld refinement studies, the transition between KFeO
2
and K
0.7
FeO
2
changed the FeO
4
volumes and inter-tetrahedra angles. Though reversible changes are possible during the initial cycles, repeated movements in the atomic arrangements with prolonged cycling appear to induce structural instability and, ultimately, amorphitization. Results of the present study suggest that an elaborate mitigation (e.g., isovalent doping) of the Jahn-Teller effect is required to improve the structural integrity of KFeO
2
, which can improve the practicality.

KFeO
2
was synthesized and examined as a novel cathode material in KIBs. We found that KFeO
2
can be reversibly charged and discharged, delivering 60 mAh g
−1
between 1.5 and 3.7 V vs. K/K
+
. Further extraction of K
+
by increasing the high-voltage cutoff resulted in an increase in the over-potentials and in a distortion of the discharge profiles with no increase in capacity. Repeated C/D cycles revealed a gradual fading of the reversible capacity. It was disclosed that the crystallinity of KFeO
2
was continuously decreased with cycling, which was associated with a deformation of FeO
4
tetrahedra. Though no obvious changes in XRD patterns were observed during C/D, a structural analysis of K
0.7
FeO
2
indicated substantial changes in the volumes and inter-tetrahdra angles of FeO
4
, which eventually led to reductions in the crystallinity and electrochemical performance of KFeO
2
. This work suggests that materials with a corner-shared connectivity between TM tetrahedra can be used as a KIB cathode, but that further structural stabilization (e.g., isovalent doping) is required for practicality.

2
and their correlation with ionic conductivity. Phys Solid State 55(5):1050–1056
